College of Chemistry and Material, Weinan Normal University Weinan 714099 PR China Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (ERCO2) represents a promising strategy for atmospheric CO2 mitigation by converting this greenhouse gas into value-added chemical feed stocks. Among various catalytic materials, copper-based electrocatalysts have emerged as frontier candidates due to their distinctive capability in promoting C-C coupling reactions, which selectively steer the reaction pathway toward multi-carbon products. Notably, these catalysts exhibit superior performance in producing industrially important C2 compounds such as ethylene and ethanol through precise modulation of reaction intermediates, thereby demonstrating significant potential for establishing a circular carbon economy. This paper provides a review of the reaction mechanism involved in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol. It also discusses the research progress made in the development of Cu-based catalysts for this reaction, including Cu monomers, Cu-based bimetallic catalysts, CuO-based catalysts and non-metallic modified Cu-based catalysts. Additionally, the paper introduces various strategies that have been employed to enhance the selectivity of ethanol products, such as the confinement strategy、local environment modulation and electronic structure modulation. Finally, the paper discusses the challenges and future development directions of Cu-based catalysts in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol. Graphical Abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide Cu-based catalyst Ethanol Electrocatalytic reduction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Since the onset of the Industrial Revolution, global carbon emissions have experienced significant growth. The concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide in 2024 exceeded 424 ppm, well above the 280.0 ppm in the 1760 s [1], and projections indicate that it is expected to rise to 600 ppm, increasing at a rate of 2.5 ppm per year [2]. The excessive release of CO2 poses substantial global risks, but it has also spurred extensive research and development efforts aimed at capturing, storing, and utilizing CO2. Among the various approaches favored by researchers, the conversion of CO2 into high value-added fuels or chemicals through carbon recycling stands out. In recent years, chemical conversion technologies for CO2 have included electrocatalytic methods [3], photocatalysis [4], thermal catalysis [5], and enzyme catalysis [6], all of which aim to achieve sustainable carbon cycling. Unlike other catalytic techniques, electrochemical reduction reactions can be conducted at ambient temperature and pressure, and the desired products can be controlled by adjusting the electrocatalyst, electrode potential, electrolyte, and electrolytic cell. This enables large-scale production under environmentally friendly conditions. ERCO2 process yields various carbon-containing compounds, including C1 products (CO, HCOOH, CH3OH and CH4), C2 products (C2H4, C2H5OH and CH3COOH) and C3 (n-CH3CH2OH) products, etc. [7]. Ethanol, one of the C2 products, has a high energy density (26.8 MJ·kg−1) and is commonly used in the production of fuels, acetic acid, and alcohol. It holds significant commercial value, with a global market size of nearly $75 billion. Ethanol is also the most promising target products when considering economic competitiveness [8]. Currently, most methods for synthesizing ethanol involve ethylene hydration, which consumes a substantial amount of energy during the production process [9] Therefore, the use of selective ERCO2 for ethanol production is highly relevant and urgent, as it not only reduces the impact of CO2 emissions but also lowers the cost of ethanol production. In order to improve energy efficiency, reaction selectivity and total conversion of CO2, various metals have been extensively studied. In 1985, Hori et al. [10] reported for the first time the detailed analysis of various catalytic products of pure metal electrodes. He and his colleagues divided these metals into four classes: (1) Production of selective catalytic formic acid using Sn, Pb, Hg, In, and Cd; (2) Formation of selective catalytic CO using Au, Ag, Zn and Ga; (3) Generation of selective catalytic hydrogen evolution reaction using Ni, Fe, Pt and Al; (4) Production of selective catalytic multi-carbon products using Cu and Cu-based electrocatalysts. An excellent catalyst should meet the following parameters for ERCO2: (1) Low potential: the difference between the actual reaction potential and the thermodynamic equilibrium potential. The lower the potential, the lower the energy consumption of the reaction; (2) High current density: the current value per square centimeter of the cathode electrode during the reaction. The higher the current density, the higher the reaction activity; (3) High Faradaic efficiency (FE): the ratio of the charge consumed by the product to the total charge during the electrolysis process. Cu has rich reserves in nature, and compared with other precious metals (Ag, Au, Pd, Pt, etc.), Cu is cheap, non-toxic and harmless to the environment, easy to recover, and can catalyze CO2 to produce a variety of selective catalytic multi-carbon products. Cu-based materials have been playing an important role in the field of electrochemistry [11] Therefore, research on Cu-based catalysts is the key to achieve efficient electric reduction of CO2 to ethanol. Cu can not only reduce CO2 to CO, HCOO-, but also deeply reduce CO2 to the reduction products above two electron transfer (CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, etc.) [12]. Through theoretical calculation and analysis, Bagger et al. found that unique ability of Cu may be due to the fact that it is the only metal with negative adsorption energy for CO and positive adsorption energy for H [13]. Cu has moderate adsorption capacity for CO and can stably adsorb CO intermediates. The CO intermediates can be coupled with each other later to form C2 products. Due to the positive adsorption energy of Cu for H, the CO intermediates can continue to add H to protonate and generate subsequent carbon compounds. To gain a deeper understanding of this ethanol production by electroreduction of CO2 using Cu-based catalysts, this review recalls the main advances in Cu-based catalysts for the ERCO2 to produce ethanol in the last few years. Firstly, the reaction mechanism of electric reduction of CO2 to ethanol over Cu-based catalysts is elaborated. Secondly, various types of catalysts (Cu monomers, Cu-based bimetallic catalysts, CuO-based catalysts and non-metallic modified Cu-based catalysts) are investigated in terms of their effects on the selectivity of ERCO2. Thirdly, strategies for enhancing ethanol production selectivity (confinement strategy、local environment modulation and electronic structure modulation) are presented. Finally, the challenges in the field of ERCO2 are discussed, and the further development and industrial applications of Cu-based catalysts in the field of ERCO2 are prospected. 2 Reaction mechanism of electrochemical reduction of CO2 to ethanol ERCO2 is a reaction in which many electrons and masses are transferred to produce carbon products and water. CO2 can be converted into small carbonaceous molecules with high energy density, such as formic acid (HCOOH), carbon monoxide (CO), methanol (CH3OH), methane (CH4), and so on ( Fig. 1) [14]. Based on a thermodynamic study, a variety of half-reactions and their corresponding electrode potentials in aqueous solution are listed in Table 1 [7,15].The electroreduction of CO2 to ethanol involves the transfer of 12 electrons and protons [16]. CO2 molecules in the electrolyte are adsorbed on the catalyst’s surface, and after proton-coupled electron transfer, the adsorbed CO2 molecules are converted to *COOH or *OCHO [17]. These intermediates are crucial for the formation of CO and HCOOH, respectively. Additionally, if the catalyst has a strong binding energy for *CO, the reaction can continue with the formation of *OCCO through the coupling of *CO and *CO [18]. However, the carbon-carbon coupling typically requires a higher energy barrier compared to the formation of *HCOO- or *CHO from *CO [18,19]. This step is also considered a shared pathway with the production of ethylene, which can further be hydrogenated to *CH2CHO. Therefore, the subsequent step involving the intermediate *CH2CHO controls the reaction towards the production of ethylene, ethanol [20,21]. The possible reaction mechanism is detailed in Fig. 2. In the ERCO2 process, the formation of the intermediate CO2* is considered the rate-determining step in the production of multi-carbons (C2+) [22]. When the active site exhibits a strong adsorption capacity for C1 products, it promotes carbon-carbon coupling and accelerates the production of C2+ products. Thus, stabilizing the intermediate CO2* and controlling the intermediate *CH2CHO towards ethanol production are crucial for achieving efficient ethanol production [23,24]. 3 Cu-based catalysts In catalytic reactions, all components have an effect on the catalytic activity. According to the different components and catalyst functions other than Cu, it can be further divided into monometal, bimetal, Cu oxides and non-metallic modified Cu-based catalysts. Whether Cu is combined with other substances to form monometrics, biometrics or supported catalysts, the addition of different ligands or metals will affect the chemical state of Cu, change the adsorption energy of intermediates, and then affect the ERCO2 performance. Specifically, the probabilistic defect sites created when Cu binds to non-metallic atoms favor the formation of C2 products. At the same time, the introduction of heteroatoms or organic groups can further improve the micro-environment around the catalyst, and have a positive effect on the further protonation process of CO2 molecules. The introduction of another metal in the catalyst is conducive to the stabilization of the catalytic active center, and a large number of *CO intermediates involved in the subsequent reaction are transported to the Cu site, which is conducive to the formation of ethanol. Table 2 summarizes representative works on Cu-based catalysts for ethanol in recent years. 3.1 Cu monomers The Cu surface demonstrates a favorable adsorption energy for key reaction intermediates in the reduction of carbon dioxide to ethanol. However, Cu still faces challenges such as poor stability and low product selectivity. To address these issues, researchers have focused on improving the morphology, size, and crystal type of Cu to enhance the selectivity of the reduced products. Kim et al. [25] investigated that a wrinkled Cu catalyst featuring high facets was synthesized through a chemical vapor deposition graphene growth process, demonstrating enhanced ethanol production efficiency ( Fig. 3). The synthesized wrinkled Cu film displayed a distinct hill-and-valley periodic structure, predominantly featuring (200) and (310) high-index facets. This configuration offered a significantly increased density of Cu step-sites, approximately 6.6 times higher than that of an electropolished flat Cu film. The uniquely structured wrinkled Cu film exhibited exceptional ethanol selectivity, reaching a FE of 40 % at −0.9 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). This performance ranks among the highest reported for Cu-based catalysts in CO2 conversion. However, Chen et al. [97] found that a method to control grain growth during copper electrodeposition by incorporating poly (vinylpyrrolidone) as an additive. The resulting grain-boundary-rich copper exhibited high selectivity (70 %) for converting CO₂ into ethylene and ethanol across a broad potential range from −1.0 to −1.3 V (vs. RHE). In situ attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy reveals that the grain boundaries promote the adsorption of the critical intermediate (*CO) on the copper surface, thereby enhancing CO2 reduction efficiency. Yang et al. [113] investigated the in situ electronic structure of Cu nanocatalysts during the electroreduction process and observed that Cu nanoclusters were reduced by surface oxides, leading to the desorption of ligands and gradual aggregation of internal Cu nanoparticles. This aggregation resulted in the formation of active Cu nanoparticles with a high density of reactive under coordination at grain boundaries, thereby enhancing the selectivity of C2+ products. Gao et al. [43] prepared Cu nanocubic catalysts with tunable Cu (100) facets, defect content, and oxygen content through low-pressure plasma treatment. These catalysts exhibited high selectivities for ethanol and n-propanol (22 % FE for ethanol), indicating that different Cu facet exposures and surface structures significantly influence catalyst performance. 3.2 Cu-based bimetallic catalysts The rational incorporation of another metal to create a bimetallic catalyst allows for the full utilization of the advantages of each metal and significantly enhances the selectivity of Cu-based materials for deep reduction products. Bimetallic catalysts have attracted a lot of academic research because of their excellent selectivity, good activity and lasting stability[67,114]. Shang et al. [68] synthesized a bimetallic, low-entropy Cu3Sn catalyst for efficient electrocatalytic CO2 reduction to ethanol. The catalyst achieves a remarkable FE of 64 % for ethanol production and demonstrates exceptional stability, maintaining performance for over 48 h at an industrial-level current density of −900 mA·cm−2 in a membrane-electrode assembly electrolyzer. Theoretical analysis revealed that the high ethanol selectivity of Cu3Sn is driven by its strong adsorption of critical intermediates involved in the ethanol formation pathway. Ren et al. [67] synthesized a series of oxide-derived CuxZn catalysts and employed them as catalysts for the enhanced electroreduction of CO2 to ethanol. It was found that the CO2 was reduced more preferentially on metallic rather than oxide surfaces using operando Raman spectroscopy. With representative potential of −1.05 V (vs. RHE), FE of 29.1 %, current density of −8.2 mA·cm−2 and maximal ethanol formation were observed. The Cu4Zn maintained stable ethanol production over 5 h. By performing CO2 reduction on Cu-Ni and Cu-Ag bimetallic catalysts, it was demonstrated that the significance of CO-producing sites for selective ethanol. More importantly, they proposed that two-site mechanism for the electroreduction of CO2 to ethanol. Zhuang et al. [115] also prepared Cu2S-Cu-V core-shell catalysts to achieve efficient electrochemical CO2 reduction to propanol and ethanol. They found that these catalysts shift selectivity away from the competing ethylene reaction and towards liquid alcohols. Hu et al. [116] prepared Mo4+-doped CuS nanosheet-assembled hollow spheres for ERCO2 to ethanol in flow cells. They found that the incorporation of Mo4+ ions induces electronic structure modulation in CuS, creating various binding sites of CuS that simultaneously enhance linear *COL coverage and promote bridge *COB formation, thereby facilitating the favorable *COL-*COH coupling pathway for selective ethanol production. From their results, it was observed that the Mo 9.0 %-CuS catalyst achieves exceptional CO2-to-ethanol conversion performance in flow cell systems, delivering a FE of 67.5 % and ethanol partial current density of 186.5 mA·cm−2 at an applied potential of −0.6 V (vs. RHE). Sun et al. [84] prepared V-doped Cu2Se nanotubes with a hierarchical structure and employed them as catalysts for the CO2 electroreduction to ethanol. The high efficiency and selectivity of CO2 electroreduction to ethanol was achieved ( Fig. 4) [85]. The results can be attributed to the change of local charge distribution of Cu2Se and the increase active sites by doping substitutional vanadium. It was worth that the distinctive active sites facilitate the formation of bridge *COB, followed by its hydrogenation to *COH, which subsequently undergoes coupling of *COH and *COL eventually produced ethanol. Wang et al. [117] carried out experiments with different model Cu-based catalysts, by modifying Cu nanowires with Ag nanoparticles (AgCu NW) and Ag single atoms (Ag1Cu NW), respectively, to study the C-C coupling mechanisms in ERCO2. From their results, the C2 selectivity in CO2 reduction to ethanol is enhanced by over 10 times when using Ag1Cu NW instead of AgCu NW. Operando/in-situ characterization combined with theoretical simulations reveal that the improved ethanol selectivity on Ag1CuNW originates from atomically dispersed Ag sites promoting H2O dissociation. This enhancement facilitates *CO hydrogenation into *CHO intermediates and enables efficient asymmetric *CO-*CHO coupling at adjacent Cu-Ag atomic pairs ( Fig. 5(a)-(b). Fig. 5(c) gave schematic showing the ERCO2 pathway over Ag1Cu NW. This result was consistent with those reported elsewhere [62]. By leveraging thermally induced atomic reorganization in immiscible Ag-Cu systems, Cai et al. [62] engineered a core-shell architecture with precisely controlled interfacial hierarchies through controlled annealing processes. The atomic Ag-Cu interactions confirmed that the increasing the electrochemical surface area and expedite charge dynamics yields the increase in an unprecedented electrocatalytic performance. The sustainably high FE of ethanol was 52.6 % at the current density of ∼320 mA·cm−2 at −1.0 V, achieving a cathodic energy conversion efficiency of 27.0 % in ERCO2. From mechanism studies, it could be concluded that locally generated CO intermediates undergo preferential accumulation at the core region, followed by driven migration to the continuous Cu surface, where energetically favorable C-C coupling facilitates selective ethanol formation. Iyengar and other researchers carried out the similar studies [118]. Structural sensitivity effects were applied by Iyengar et al. [118] to elucidate the ethanol-producing active sites on Cu-Ag ERCO2 tandem catalysts. They found that ethanol is selectively enhanced via the *CHx-*CO coupling pathway at the terraces of Cu nano-octahedra-Ag in the *CO-enriched environment generated by the Ag nanospheres. In addition, on Cu nanocubes-Ag, ethanol was selectively formed through the same way at the edges and corners of Cu nanocubes, while ethylene continued to be produced at the terraces. 3.3 CuO-based catalysts Metal oxides exhibited superior catalytic efficiency compared to untreated copper metal. It has been demonstrated that the FE of C2H5OH was 9.7 % at −1.05 V (vs. RHE) for copper metal, whereas the catalyst derived from copper metal oxides achieved a current density of 11.8 mA·cm−2 at −1.0 V (vs. RHE) with an FE of 35 % for ethanol [119]. The effect of different morphologies of CuO on ERCO2 was investigated, and spherical nanostructured CuO catalysts in 0.2 mol·L−1 KI electrolyte obtained an experimental ethanol current efficiency of 34.1 % [120]. CuO-loaded catalysts on Cu electrodes were prepared using a hydrothermal method, where CuO was reduced to Cu(111) nanoparticles, resulting in improved current density and significantly reduced over potential (vs. RHE) [121]. The presence of Cu+ or Cu2+ plays a crucial role in the ERCO2 process, but in some cases, the reducing potential (vs. Hg/HgO reference electrode) can cause the rapid conversion of oxide Cu-based catalysts to metallic Cu [122]. The selectivity and stability of oxide Cu-based catalysts are influenced by the reduction potential (vs. RHE). Lu et al. [33] conducted a study in which catalysts with varying CuO/Cu+ concentration ratios were prepared through electrodeposition. It was observed that when the ratio is at its optimal level, the FE of ethanol production can reach 48 % at −0.6 V (vs. RHE). The findings of the study indicate that the interface between Cu+ and its adjacent Cu metal sites plays a beneficial role in facilitating C-C coupling, thereby significantly enhancing the selectivity of the catalyst and facilitating the formation of ethanol. Consequently, controlling the morphology of Cu metal oxide catalysts to promote C-C coupling emerges as a crucial avenue for the production of ethanol through ERCO2. Zhang et al. [123] firstly prepared Cu2O hollow spheres using hydrothermal method. Subsequently, they used Cu2O and Aux to synthesize Aux/Cu2O composites. They found that Aux/Cu2O presented the higher FE ethanol and the inhibition to the hydrogen evolution reaction. Drawing upon the tandem catalyst reaction mechanism, the authors attributed the elevation in the FE of C2 products observed in the Aux/Cu2O composite catalysts to the phenomenon where an increased Au content resulted in a heightened abundance of *CO intermediates. These intermediates were adsorbed onto the Cu sites and subsequently engaged in the C-C coupling reaction, thereby facilitating the production of ethanol. Yang et al. [59] prepared Cu2O nanoparticles with multiple cavities and employed them as catalysts for conversion of CO2. From their results, it was observed that the spatial confinement of the carbon intermediates, generated in situ within the Cu2O cavities, was adequate to prevent the reduction of Cu+ during ERCO2, thereby stabilizing the oxidation state of copper ( Fig. 6). Furthermore, these cavities effectively retained the in situ generated C1 intermediates, enabling them to cover the active sites and facilitating their further involvement in the coupling reaction. Consequently, this process promoted the formation of C2 products (ethanol). It was found to be a remarkable C2+ FE of 75.2 ± 2.7 %, achieved at a C2+ partial current density of 267 ± 13 mA·cm−2. Additionally, C2+-to-C1 ratio of approximately 7.2 was obtained. Lin et al. [124] discovered that within a broad potential range (vs. RHE), the synthesized CuOx exclusively yielded C2H5OH, outperforming all other ERCO2 products. More significantly, a mechanism involving the stabilization of carbonyl groups by boundary OH species was proposed, which effectively hindered the protonation of terminal oxygen sites on hydrocarbons. This innovative approach resulted in the production of an oxygenated ERCO2 product-specifically, ethanol in this instance with remarkable selectivity. 3.4 Non-metallic modified Cu-based catalysts The defect site generated when Cu binds to non-metallic atoms is conducive to the formation of C2 products. At the same time, the introduction of heteroatoms or organic groups can further improve the microenvironment around the catalyst, and have a positive effect on the further protonation process of CO2 molecules. Cu-based catalysts modified with nonmetals can be an effective method for enhancing the activity of ERCO2 in ethanol production. By introducing non-metallic elements such as nitrogen, boron, and sulfur, this method not only alters the electronic structure of the catalyst but also improves its stability and activity. K doping promotes high adsorption of key intermediates such as linear *COL and bridged *COB on the catalyst surface. This enhancement promotes C-C coupling for ethanol production, even at the high current density of −97.3 mA·cm−2 [85]. Similarly, Sun et al. [84] used vanadium doped (V doped) Cu2Se nanotube catalyst to synthesize single-liquid product ethanol using a flow cell. It is worth noting that the Cu1.22V0.19Se catalyst exhibited an ethanol-generated FE of 68.3 % and a partial current density of −207.9 mA·cm−2 at a drop potential of −0.80 V on gas diffusion electrode. In this process, H2 production is negligible. In sharp contrast, the CuSe catalyst does not produce ethanol, but produces a large amount of H2 [125]. The incorporation of V4+ doped ions into the Cu2Se lattice is thought to modify the active site and protect Cu+ species from being reduced to Cu0 in the ERCO2. Thus, this results in an increase in electrochemical performance. Yuan et al. [126] successfully designed Cu nanoparticles modified with N-doped graphene oxide (GO-VB6-Cu), which exhibited a maximum FE of 56.3 % for ethanol at −0.25 V (vs. RHE) and demonstrated excellent stability. Zhuang et al. [115] found that incorporating sulfur atoms in Cu nanoparticles significantly enhanced ethanol selectivity. The Cu vacancies created in the nanoparticle shell layer and the sulfur atoms in the core were responsible for the increase in ethanol yield, as calculated by the density functional theory. Wirawan et al. [127] obtained the Cu3(BTC)2 catalyst by calcining Cu-based MOF material, and in the ERCO2 experiment, they observed an ethanol FE of 49.0 % at a current density of 6 mA·cm−2. Su et al. [39] developed a nitrogen-doped Cu-based catalyst that achieved a 72 % FE of C2+ products and a 51 % FE of ethanol at −1.1 V (vs. RHE). Therefore, the introduction of non-metallic elements can alter the electronic structure, surface properties, and active sites of Cu-based catalysts, influencing the adsorption and desorption of ERCO2 intermediates and enabling a more efficient and stable reduction of CO2 to ethanol. Liu et al. [44] engineered a chlorine-modified copper catalyst (Cu-Cl) to enhance the electrochemical CO2 to-ethanol conversion. Under optimized conditions at −0.74 V (vs. RHE), the Cu-Cl catalyst achieved a remarkable ethanol FE of 26.2 % and a partial current density of 343.2 mA·cm−2, representing a 1.66-fold and 1.76-fold improvement, respectively, over the unmodified Cu catalyst. They found that Cl-modified Cu surfaces exhibit enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation through strengthened Cu-CO2 interactions. Significantly, the Cl modification simultaneously suppressed the competing hydrogen evolution reaction while promoting *H species formation. The calculated Gibbs free energy profiles revealed that Cl decoration effectively lowers both: (i) the activation energy barrier for the critical C-C coupling step ( Fig. 7(a)), and (ii) the formation energy of key intermediates along the ethanol pathway (Fig. 7(b)). Compared to pristine Cu, these synergistic effects on Cl-modified Cu surfaces collectively promote selective ethanol formation (Fig. 7(c)). It is particularly noteworthy that Wang et al. previously demonstrated chlorine-induced mixed-valence CuOx/C catalysts could effectively promote the electrochemical CO2 reduction toward ethylene production [128]. 4 Strategies for enhancing ethanol production selectivity The presence of ethylene as a significant competitor to ethanol in the ERCO2 poses challenges in consistently enhancing the selectivity of ethanol in the reaction. However, recent research has demonstrated that promoting the C-C coupling process can lead to improved selectivity towards ethanol as a product. Altering the active sites on the surface, enhancing *CO adsorption, and adjusting the charge environment can all have an impact on the C-C coupling process. Nevertheless, achieving precise control over the selectivity of ethanol as a product remains a formidable task. 4.1 Confinement strategy The carbon coating strategy employs physical/chemical methods to construct a protective carbon interface layer, which significantly improves ethanol selectivity through dual mechanisms stabilization of active Cu+ species and precise modulation of intermediate adsorption configurations. It has been demonstrated that the intermediate valence state of Cu serves as the actual active center of the catalyst. The presence of a carbon coating on the surface of the CuOx catalyst effectively hinders the reduction of Cu+ and stabilizes the Cu+ active site under CO2 electroreduction conditions. Additionally, the carbon coating can regulate the electronic interactions between the active site and the intermediate species, influencing the C-C coupling reaction. This regulation facilitates the entry of the key intermediate *HOCCH into the hydrogenation pathway of ethanol production, thereby impacting the selectivity of C2+ ethanol production. Zang et al. [129] synthesized a carbon-coated CuO (CuO@C) catalyst using one-pot pyrolysis of Cu-based metal-organic framework, which achieved a remarkable ethanol partial current density of 166 mA·cm−2 with 46 % FE. The carbon coating in CuO@C composites plays a crucial dual role in ERCO2 by simultaneously stabilizing Cu active species and enhancing C2+ production. This promotional effect stems from the carbon-induced reaction microenvironment that facilitates reactant adsorption and concentrates reaction intermediates at the active sites [130]. Moreover, the conductive carbon layer significantly improves charge transfer efficiency, enabling rapid electron delivery from the external circuit to catalytic surfaces. This enhanced electron transfer not only accelerates reactant conversion kinetics but also effectively suppresses the self-reduction of CuOx species during electrocatalysis. In all, the surface carbon coating efficiently stabilizes the abundant Cu+ species, thereby enhancing C-C coupling through improved *CO adsorption and modulating the crucial intermediate *HOCCH in the hydrogenation pathway for ethanol production. Thus, The CuO@C demonstrates enhanced selectivity toward ethanol production during ERCO2 ( Fig. 8). Wang et al. [45] enhanced the selectivity of ethanol products during carbon dioxide electroreduction by applying a nitrogen-doped carbon layer to the copper surface and confining the active catalyst with a cladding layer possessing strong electron-donor capabilities. This approach effectively inhibits the simultaneous reaction of the intermediate HOCCH deoxygenation to ethylene. Ren et al. [95] prepared thin films of Cu2O through electrodeposition and systematically adjusted the FE of ethylene and ethanol by varying the thickness of the deposited overlayer. For a film thickness of 1.7 μm, the FE of ethylene and ethanol were 38.8 % and 9.0 %, respectively, while for a film thickness of 3.6 μm (-0.99 V vs. RHE), the FE were 34.3 % and 16.4 %, respectively. 4.2 Local environment modulation Compared to monometallic catalysts, Cu-based catalysts doped with alkali metals offer several advantages, including small over potentials (vs. RHE), a wide range of product options, high current density, and high FE. The addition of alkali metals to Cu-based catalysts allows researchers to modify the electronic structure of the catalysts, which in turn affects the interactions between the catalyst's active sites and the reaction intermediates. This modification can improve the selectivity of CO2 reduction by adjusting the binding capacity of the active intermediates *COOH and *CO. Ding et al. [85] found that K doping into CuSe nanosheet arrays precisely modulates the interaction between Cu sites and reaction intermediates during the ERCO2, resulting in improved selectivity for ethanol production. K doping promotes the adsorption of linear *COL and bridge *COB intermediates on the catalyst surface, which facilitates the formation of *COOH and the subsequent C-O bond breaking process, ultimately enhancing the C-C coupling required for ethanol production. This promotion is achieved through the protection of the Cu(I) site by K doping in the ERCO2 process. Wu et al. [131] constructed an ultrastable CuOδ+ catalytic site on a copper penetration electrode through boron(B) doping, which precisely tailors the *CO adsorption strength and configuration to promote C-C coupling ( Fig. 9). This innovative design achieves remarkable performance with a C2+ FE of 78.9 % at −0.91 V (vs. RHE), including an ethanol FE of 52.4 % and an unprecedented partial current density of 1.25 A·cm−2, significantly surpassing state-of-the-art electrocatalysts. From their result, it was confirmed that B incorporation optimizes the coordination environment and oxidation states of surface Cu atoms, enriching locally asymmetric *COatop and *CHO intermediates to drive asymmetric C-C coupling, thereby selectively steering the reaction pathway toward ethanol formation. The similar results were reported by Yu et al. [86]. They found that the integration of elemental B into Cu catalysts creates extra binding sites for *CO intermediates, which boosts the production yield of preferred ethanol production. Luo et al. [35] investigated a series of Cu catalysts doped with metal-hydroxide interfaces and found that Ce(OH)x-doped Cu catalysts exhibited a FE as high as 43 % and a partial current density as high as 128 mA·cm−2 for the reduction of CO2 to ethanol. Mechanistic studies combining hydrogen precipitation and Raman spectroscopic results revealed that the adsorbed hydrogen on the catalyst surface undergoes hydrotreatment with *HCCOH intermediates to produce ethanol, with *HCCOH being the key factor determining the formation of ethanol. The presence of *HCCOH as an intermediate determines whether ethanol or ethylene is produced. 4.3 Electronic structure modulation Strategic modulation of catalyst electronic structure directly through precise microstructure engineering offers an effective pathway to enhance ethanol selectity by optimizing the interfacial interaction between active sites and key reaction intermediates. This approach enables targeted regulation of adsorption configurations and electronic environments that preferentially stabilize critical intermediates involved in C-C coupling, thereby steering the reaction pathway toward selective ethanol formation while suppressing competing reaction channels. The deliberate structural modifications at atomic and nanoscale levels create favorable electronic states that lower the energy barrier for asymmetic C-C coupling, ultimately improving both the activity and selectivity of ethanol production in the ERCO2. In addition, by regulating the coordination number of metal atoms on the catalyst, the electronic structure of metal atoms can be changed, thus affecting the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Liu et al. [49] introduced a strategy to adjust the electron delocalization of the Cu catalyst through surface functionalization with nitrene, which facilitates the weakening and breaking of the Cu-O bond in the adsorbed CH2═CHO* species. Additionally, this approach accelerates the hydrogenation of the C═C bond, promoting the ethanol formation pathway. Consequently, the Cu catalyst functionalized with nitrene demonstrates a significantly enhanced FE for ethanol production, reaching 45 %, accompanied by a peak partial current density of 406 mA·cm−2. Zhang et al. [132] found that TiO2 forms a heterojunction with Cu2O, resulting in electron redistribution at the interface. This electronic structure rearrangement causes a more positive charge to accumulate on Ti, enhancing the oxygenicity of TiO2 and subsequently increasing the binding strength of the CObridge intermediate. This change facilitates a mixed CObridge and COatop adsorption configuration that triggers CObridge-COatop coupling, which is more energetically advantageous and promotes ethanol generation. In addition, the formation of Cu2O-TiO2 heterojunction creates distinct CObridge adsorption preferences compared to pure Cu2O, with CObridge becoming more stabilized while COatop remains favorable on Cu2O alone. This TiO2-induced modulation of adsorption behavior strongly enhances the CObridge binding capability. More importantly, the heterojunction significantly lowers the activation barrier for asymmetric CObridge-COatop coupling relative to symmetric COatop-COatop coupling on pristine Cu2O. The synergistic effect between Cu2O and TiO2 not only promotes preferential CObridge adsorption but also establishes an energetically favorable pathway for asymmetric C-C coupling, which collectively contributes to enhanced ethanol generation during ERCO2 ( Fig. 10). Jin et al. [133] modulated the coordination number of Cu single atoms on In2O3 and found that the presence of three-coordinated Cu atoms is advantageous in adjusting the electron distribution of the catalyst to positions that are conducive to CO2 reduction, ultimately leading to improved selectivity of ethanol. This favorable structure optimizes the adsorption of intermediates and accelerates the OC-COH coupling reaction, thereby enhancing the selectivity of ethanol production from ERCO2. In conclusion, regulating the electronic structure of the catalyst can affect the selectivity of ethanol by changing the electron density distribution, charge redistribution, orbital overlap and coordination number of the active site. This provides an effective way to design efficient and highly selective catalysts[134]. 5 Conclusions and future perspectives Nowadays, the world is facing the problem of energy shortage and greenhouse effect caused by excessive CO2. Electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to produce ethanol is an effective method. This paper provides a summary of the current research progress in ethanol production using Cu-based catalysts for the electroreduction of CO2. It is concluded that electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 faces several problems: (1) Most researches do not report single conversion efficiency; (2) The catalysts currently used have poor selectivity for specific products. Based on above problems, the following observations are proposed for further research direction. (1) Rational design of electrocatalysts based on the existing mechanism of ethanol synthesis from ERCO2. This involves creating more C-C coupling active sites through oxidative treatment, morphology control, and alloying surface modification of the catalysts to enhance the formation of ethanol intermediates and increase electrochemical selectivity. (2) In-depth exploration of the unclear reaction mechanism of ethanol production by ERCO2. This can be achieved through in situ characterization techniques and theoretical calculations to develop electrocatalytic materials that facilitate the evolution of C-C coupling intermediates and electron transfer, leading to more efficient electrocatalytic materials. (3) Attention should be paid to how to translate lab-scale Cu-based catalyst technology to industrial-scale production. This includes the development of catalyst synthesis methods suitable for large-scale mold production, as well as the design of integrated CO2 capture, conversion and product separation systems. (4) An key intermediates and specific formation ways of CO2 electrocatalytic reaction products still need to be explored. coredata.dc:description: Electrochemical reduction of CO2 (ERCO2) represents a promising strategy for atmospheric CO2 mitigation by converting this greenhouse gas into value-added chemical feed stocks. Among various catalytic materials, copper-based electrocatalysts have emerged as frontier candidates due to their distinctive capability in promoting C-C coupling reactions, which selectively steer the reaction pathway toward multi-carbon products. Notably, these catalysts exhibit superior performance in producing industrially important C2 compounds such as ethylene and ethanol through precise modulation of reaction intermediates, thereby demonstrating significant potential for establishing a circular carbon economy. This paper provides a review of the reaction mechanism involved in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol. It also discusses the research progress made in the development of Cu-based catalysts for this reaction, including Cu monomers, Cu-based bimetallic catalysts, CuO-based catalysts and non-metallic modified Cu-based catalysts. Additionally, the paper introduces various strategies that have been employed to enhance the selectivity of ethanol products, such as the confinement strategy、local environment modulation and electronic structure modulation. Finally, the paper discusses the challenges and future development directions of Cu-based catalysts in the electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to ethanol.
